paragraphs.text: Mark,

paragraphs.name: f260
paragraphs.text: Great article.

paragraphs.name: 6ab4
paragraphs.text: Keep dreaming, beaming, and achieving and ignore the noise generated by those that cannot fathom the depths of your commitment.

paragraphs.name: d844
paragraphs.text: This post is a perfect example of why you should always understand the value add of the right partner whether it be a lawyer, board member, VC or who knows whomever. You’re one hell of an advocate Mark, I’m sure you helped Meredith and her team get some sleep.

paragraphs.text: Hi Mark, great response, thank you! I also happen to be one the investors backing Ubeam (through OurCrowd) and your articles have given me a great deal of comfort with the company and team. A proposition as bold as Ubeam's will always have its doubters and naysayers and, while the company could indeed fail (investors and stakeholders should always…

paragraphs.name: 15a3
paragraphs.text: Thoughtful response Mark. Regardless of whether a low cost feasable product is ever delivered, a press grilling is hard for startups. I have had my share and it just made us stronger…and deliver even better product. Hoping it does the same for this team.

virtuals.subtitle: Full disclosure, I am invested in a competitor, but am empathetic to Marc’s post. If an investor doesn’t support an entrepreneur when the…

paragraphs.name: 11c1
paragraphs.text: Last night, my friend Bryan Johnson received an alumni award from Chicago Booth. We agreed that several times in a successful startups life, it looks like it is going to fail. How you navigate that water is sometimes what determines the fate.

paragraphs.text: Every startUp should have investors who not only intimately know their business but are willing to go the distance in their belief of that business and the team. I think your comment about believing in the CEO and willing to fund her next venture says it all.

virtuals.subtitle: The media happily push the fairy tale around until the difficulty of reality brutally sets in, at which point they happily push the scandal…

paragraphs.text: LudWitt sums up best what’s so irritating about the latest wave of overblown startup claims: nowadays the claim/story/hype predates even the slightest trace of fact, and the bolder the claim the better.

paragraphs.text: Great support in a tough situation for the team. Of course the best way to prove the naysayers wrong is to “ship” and focus on that rather than the publicity negative or positive. The product sounds exciting and I hope it works — if so it will be a game changer. And if it doesn’t the world won’t end and as long as investors and employees went in eyes…

b15002cb401c.title: Great support in a tough situation for the team.

virtuals.subtitle: I love that if it fails, YOU’D be the next in line to fund Meredith’s next venture.

paragraphs.text: You’re an inspiration.

paragraphs.text: The world needs more like you.

content.subtitle: I love that if it fails, YOU’D be the next in line to fund Meredith’s next venture.

paragraphs.name: 75c4
paragraphs.text: I hope there’s a kernel of legitimacy in the product. VCs have already become growth equity, and there are so few funds really investing in venture ideas, that this might be the straw that broke the camel’s back should the whole thing prove to be a ruse. I’m rooting for you; if for nothing else than the promise of what venture is supposed to be.

cdf513765815.title: I hope there’s a kernel of legitimacy in the product.

paragraphs.text: Great post Mark, love the reality of it all. While we’ve never had such high visibility, dealing with ex-employees / founders with a grudge is always difficult and as you say, it’s not worth getting angry — that’s just a waste of energy.

paragraphs.name: 6e24
paragraphs.text: I’m really amazed that of all the people who commented here, only Pasmon Vrainom seems to have expressed any skepticism and perhaps actually read Paul Reynolds’ blog or looked at the IEEE Spectrum article on uBeam. From the IEEE Spectrum article:

paragraphs.name: 6b25
paragraphs.text: I wish hard work was published more than controversies and close knit teams were celebrated more than departing colleagues but it does not work that way. I also wish the power beamed wirelessly but it does not work that way too. Don’t sweat over what you cannot alter but rather work to change what you can. Work hard little uBeam, you will beam power some day and make us all proud.

c60593eb2057.title: I wish hard work was published more than controversies and close knit teams were celebrated more…

virtuals.subtitle: “Were she a shy, pimply, awkward male engineer with a pocket protector she would fit an archetype that would make sense to observers.”

paragraphs.name: fc00
paragraphs.text: “Has her vision risen to the level of personal attacks she has to receive in the press or the claims of falsifying information?”

paragraphs.text: That is what is called having someone’s back. And that’s why when you choose to partner with an Angel or a VC, you need to look at a lot more than a term sheet. I don’t know how all of this will play out (and I know nothing about Mark other than the many blog posts I have read over the past few years), but I do know having someone like Mark in your corner is priceless.

a858030ac194.title: That is what is called having someone’s back.

virtuals.subtitle: In case you missed it, the press yesterday ran several stories questioning the viability of a wireless charging company I invested in…

paragraphs.text: Mark, she is lucky to have you as an investor, advisor and board member. This was a great post.

It seems today that young, talented founders are too often seduced by the idea of being the next “rockstar” CEO. Perhaps it’s the Zuckerberg effect combined with the ease in which you can publish content and get followers in today…

paragraphs.name: 55b4
paragraphs.text: Sounds more like admiration or may be a crush on Perry than actual faith in the tech. Scientists are skeptical and smart investors should be concerned. To make wireless charging work will take a major discovery a la discovery of electricity or silicon which may take years, decades or even centuries. It’s possible that the team will “stumble” on such…

paragraphs.text: Any entrepreneur is lucky to have you supporting them.

paragraphs.name: 13f1
paragraphs.text: Trying is not failing, it is always a learning experience. Your article reminds me of this loosely-paraphrased, but thoroughly appropriate, quote attributed to Thomas Edison in inventing the longer burning, tungsten-filament incandescent light bulb, wherein he stated that he “had not failed seven hundred times,” he had “learned seven hundred ways an incandescent bulb would not work.”

a7ee07cd68d2.title: Trying is not failing, it is always a learning experience.

paragraphs.name: 1fad
paragraphs.text: Love how you have your entrepreneurs’ back!

ea4935a5b534.title: Love how you have your entrepreneurs’ back!

paragraphs.name: de35
paragraphs.text: It’s not just about writing an investment check, but also being there for the entrepreneur when they need it most. Other investors can learn from this.

paragraphs.name: e30d
paragraphs.text: Thanks for writing this, Mark. I’ve been a big admirer of Meredith Perry and uBeam since I first saw her demo the tech. I’m definitely rooting for you guys. It seems that the press wants uBeam to be realistic and it reminds me of an article I wrote a while back on dealing with skeptics:

Great post, Mark Suster .. As a hardware founder who’s had an early taste of media scrutiny, I admire you for speaking up for the team. Delays are unfortunately inevitable with most new technologies and in a world of Amazon, consumers (and media) are conditioned to expect things NOW. Question: do you believe female founders catch more heat from the…

paragraphs.text: If for any reason we fall short of expectations we have set in the market, I will be the first person in line to admit it and then to immediately fund Meredith’s next company. Her strengths so vastly outweigh any weaknesses and her vision, tenacity and resiliency far exceed any perceived limitations.
paragraphs.name: 2d50
032c
paragraphs.text: Back to work, I hope. I told Meredith I would write this because I really want her focusing her energy on the only thing that ultimately will decide the fate of uBeam — shipping a product.
